Use voices expressively to speak, chant, and sing (imitate sounds of animals and sounds in the home and neighborhood).
Sing a variety of simple songs in various keys, meters, and genres, alone and with a group, becoming increasingly accurate in rhythm and pitch.
Sing simple songs from memory individually and in groups.
Demonstrate the difference between a singing voice and a speaking voice.
Imitate two pitch (sol-mi) patterns.
Demonstrate steady beat when singing.
Use the singing voice to echo short melodic patterns.
Sing from memory a variety of simple songs, echoes, and chants, individually and in groups, with accuracy.
Develop a repertoire of songs with and without accompaniment.
Demonstrate use of pitch (high/low, upward/downward, melody skips, repeats. melodic patterns, ostinatos) and timbre of the voice.
Demonstrate melodic rhythm when singing.
Sing a variety of songs in various keys, meters, and genres, alone and with a group, with accuracy in rhythm and pitch, from memory.
Develop a repertoire of songs, including those with and without accompaniment, with and without harmony, and songs with ostinatos and meter in 2 and 3.
Match single pitches and groups of pitches played on the piano, individually, and in groups.
Read lyrics containing more than one verse and including words divided into syllables.
Sing in a two-part ensemble.
Sing from memory a variety of seasonal, game, folk, and patriotic songs with or without accompaniment.
Develop a repertoire of familiar songs from diverse cultures, including melodies, rounds/canons, partner songs, and songs with ostinatos and meters in 2, 3, and 4.
Sing in tune with clear tone quality, dynamics, phrasing, pitch, diction, and interpretation.
Sing melodies within the range of an octave.
Sing from memory a varied repertoire of songs from diverse cultures, including countermelodies, rounds/canons, partner songs, descants, and songs with ostinatos, alone and with others.
Sing independently with good pitch, diction, and posture, and maintain a steady tempo.
Distinguish between the "head voice" (high register, light tone color) and the "chest voice" (low register, heavy tone color).

Sing from memory a varied repertoire of songs representing diverse genres, styles and cultures, including rounds/canons, descants, and songs with ostinatos and songs in two-part harmony, alone and with others.
Sing with accurate pitch, rhythm, diction, and posture, maintaining a steady tempo.
Sing in groups, blending vocal timbres, dynamic levels, and respond to the cues of the conductor.
Sing music representing diverse genres and cultures, with expression appropriate for the work being performed.
Sing a varied repertoire of vocal literature, alone and in ensembles, demonstrating good posture, tone quality, vowel formation, and with good breath control.
Sing music written in two and/or three parts.
Sing music representing diverse genres and cultures, with expression appropriate for the work being performed.
Sing a varied repertoire of vocal literature, alone and in ensembles, demonstrating good posture, tone quality, vowel formation, and with good breath control.
Sing music written in three and/or four parts.
Sing music representing diverse genres and cultures, with expression appropriate for the work being performed.
Sing a varied repertoire of vocal literature, alone and in ensembles, demonstrating good posture, tone quality, vowel formation, and with good breath control.
Sing music written in three and/or four parts.
Sing in small ensembles demonstrating effective balance, intonation, and rhythmic unity (level of difficulty: 4 on a scale of 1- 6).
Sing with stylistic and technical accuracy, a large and varied repertoire of vocal literature, written and memorized (level of difficulty: 4 on a scale of 1-6).
Sing music written in two, three, and/or four parts with and without accompaniment.
Sing in small ensembles, with one performer for each part, demonstrating effective balance, intonation, and rhythmic unity (level of difficulty: 5 on a scale of 1-6).
Sing with stylistic and technical accuracy, a large and varied repertoire of vocal literature, written and memorized, by oneself and in ensembles (level of difficulty: 5 on a scale of 1-6).
Sing music written in more than four parts with and without accompaniment.
Perform on Instruments:
Use a variety of instruments and other sound sources to create musical sounds.
Move or use body percussion to demonstrate awareness of beat and tempo.
Use body percussion and classroom instruments to accompany songs and chants while demonstrating a steady beat.
Perform rhythmic patterns that include long and short sounds and silences.
Match movement to rhythm patterns.
Perform simple accompaniments on pitched and non-pitched classroom instruments.
Perform rhythm patterns that include long and short sounds and repeated patterns.
Relate rhythm patterns to notation.
Demonstrate melodic rhythm (ostinato, melodic patterns).
Perform rhythmic ostinatos and single-chord accompaniments on classroom instruments.
Perform and match notated rhythm patterns.
Play instruments to demonstrate awareness of beat, tempo, dynamics, and melodic direction.
Perform (by printed notation and by note) major and minor scales.
Perform on instruments using a wide range of tempos and dynamics.
Perform in a two-part music ensemble.
Identify and perform sets of beats that are grouped in twos and threes using descriptive terminology to identify which beats are strong and which beats are weak.
Maintain instruments, voice, performance and practice areas carefully and responsibly.
Perform (by printed notation and by rote) rhythmic and melodic ostinatos and I and V (V7) chords to accompany a two-chord melody, using available pitched classroom instruments.
Perform easy rhythmic, melodic, and chordal patterns on rhythmic, melodic, and harmonic classroom instruments.
Perform on pitch, in rhythm, with appropriate dynamics and a steady tempo.
Play in instrumental groups in order to learn how to respond to the directions of a conductor.
Echo sort rhythmic and melodic patterns.
Maintain instruments, voice, performance and practice areas carefully and responsibly.

Perform melodies and accompaniments from a varied repertoire of music from diverse cultures, including rounds, descants, ostinatos, and two-part harmony, by oneself and with others, on classroom instruments.
Use appropriate embouchure and breath control, bowing or drumstick grip to produce tones on instruments.
Perform independent instrumental parts while other students sing or play contrasting parts.
Accompany singing with rhythm and/or melody instruments.
Maintain instruments, voice, performance and practice areas carefully and responsibly.

Perform on one or more instruments a repertoire of instrumental literature, representing various genres, styles, and cultures, demonstrating technical accuracy, tone quality and articulation, by oneself and in ensembles.
Perform music representing diverse genres and cultures, including special occasions, folk, and holiday.

Perform on one or more instruments a repertoire of instrumental literature, representing various genres, styles, and cultures, technical accuracy, tone quality and articulation, by oneself and in small and large ensembles.
Perform music representing diverse genres and cultures, including ethnic and contemporary pop.

Perform on one or more instruments a repertoire of instrumental literature, representing various genres, styles, and cultures (e.g. classical, jazz, and opera), with technical accuracy, tone quality and articulation, by oneself and in small and large ensembles.
Play by ear, simple melodies on a melodic instrument and simple accompaniments on a harmonic instrument.

Perform instrumental literature, representing various genres, styles, and cultures, and demonstrate technical accuracy, tone quality and articulation (level of difficulty: 4 on a scale of 1-6) on one or more instruments.
Perform on an instrument in small ensembles, demonstrating effective balance, intonation, and well-developed ensemble skills (level of difficulty: 4 on a scale of 1-6).

Perform on one or more instruments, a large and varied repertoire of instrumental literature, representing various genres, styles, and cultures, and demonstrate technical accuracy, tone quality and articulation, by oneself and in ensembles (level of difficulty: 5 on a scale of 1-6).
Perform on an instrument in small ensembles, demonstrating effective balance, intonation, and well-developed ensemble skills (level of difficulty: 5 on a scale of 1-6).
Strand 3: Improvise, arrange, and compose music.
Improvise and arrange songs to accompany play activities.
Improvise and arrange instrumental accompaniments to songs, recorded selections, stories, and poems.
Use classroom instruments to imitate and make sounds.
Imitate sounds made with the voice.
Use the voice (singing and speaking) to create accompaniments for songs, recorded selections, stories, and poems.
Create accompaniments to stories using the voice or a variety of instruments.
Imitate and create tonal patterns that ascend, descend, and repeat.
Create melodies to familiar nursery rhymes or chants.
Create tonal patterns that ascend, descend, and repeat.
Improvise simple rhythmic and melodic accompaniments, using voice, body percussion, or classroom instruments.
Improvise accompaniments and ostinatos (melodic, rhythmic) to enhance songs, stories, and poems (e.g., match sounds with visuals/images to create improvisations inspired by an event, poem or story).
Compose and arrange simple rhythmic and melodic accompaniments using voice, body percussion, or classroom instruments.
Compose, arrange, and improvise accompaniments and ostinato (melodic, rhythmic) for songs and chants.
Improvise lyrics to familiar melodies and new verses to songs.
Compose music to enhance stories and poems.
Improvise simple rhythmic and melodic ostinato accompaniments (meter in 2 and 3, dotted rhythm, syncopation).

Improvise short songs and instrumental pieces, using a variety of sound sources, including the voice, sounds available in the classroom (instruments), body sounds, and sounds produced by electronic means.

Compose and arrange short songs and instrumental pieces, using a variety of sound sources, including traditional sounds, sounds available in the classroom, body sounds, and sounds produced by electronic means.
Improvise, compose, and arrange simple melodies on a given scale (e.g., pentatonic).
Improvise, compose, and arrange basic rhythmic, melodic and harmonic patterns on classroom instruments and available technology.
Improvise, compose, and arrange music to accompany readings and dramatizations.
Improvise and compose short songs and/or instrumental pieces in duple and triple meter using the following musical devises: imitation and repetition.
Improvise, compose, and arrange melodies and harmonic accompaniments.
Improvise and compose short songs and/or instrumental pieces in duple and triple meter using the following musical devises: imitation and repetition, and ostinato.
Improvise, compose, and arrange simple melodies and harmonic accompaniments using traditional and nontraditional sources of sound, including digital/electronic (if available).
Improvise and compose simple rhythmic variations and melodic embellishments and variations on given diatonic melodies.
Improvise and compose short songs and instrumental pieces in duple and triple meter using the following musical devises: imitation and repetition, ostinato, and syncopation.
Improvise, compose, and arrange simple pieces for voice and instruments, using traditional and nontraditional sources of sound, including digital/electronic (if available).
Improvise, compose, and arrange short melodies, unaccompanied and over given rhythmic accompaniments, each in a consistent style, meter, and tonality.
Improvise and compose melodic embellishments and simple rhythmic and melodic variations on given pentatonic melodies and melodies in major keys.

Improvise, compose, and arrange short songs and instrumental pieces using the following musical devises: imitation and repetition, ostinato, syncopation, accompaniment and chord progressions, using traditional and nontraditional sources of sound, including digital/electronic (if available).
Improvise rhythmic and melodic variations on given pentatonic melodies and melodies in major and minor keys.
Improvise stylistically appropriate harmonizing parts.
Improvise original melodies over given chord progressions, each in a consistent style, meter, and tonality.
Compose music in several distinct styles, demonstrating creativity in using the elements of music (pitch, rhythm, harmony, dynamics, timbre, texture, form) for expressive effect.
Arrange simple pieces for voices or instruments other than those for which the pieces were written in ways that preserve or enhance the expressive effect of the music.
Compose and arrange music for voices and/or various acoustic and electronic instruments, demonstrating knowledge of the ranges and traditional usages of the sound sources.
Improvise rhythmic and melodic variations on given pentatonic melodies and melodies in major, minor and modal keys.
Improvise stylistically appropriate harmonizing parts in a variety of styles.
Improvise original melodies in a variety of styles, over given chord progressions, each in a consistent style, meter, and tonality
Compose music, demonstrating imagination and technical skill in applying the principles of composition.
Compose and arrange music for various combinations of voice and acoustic and digital/electronic instruments, using appropriate ranges and traditional musical devices.
Compose improvisations in a style or genre within a musical culture (e.g., gamelan, jazz, mariachi).
Strand 4: Read and notate music.
Make up physical movements to illustrate the "high & low," "up & down," and "long & short".
Recognize whole, half, and quarter notes.
Recognize symbolic representations and patterns for high/low, fast/slow, long/short, and soft/loud sounds.
Echo-clap/tap short steady beat patterns while following notation.
Recognize and produce through clapping whole, half, quarter and eighth notes.
Interpret rhythmic and tonal patterns and tempo and dynamic symbols.
Read (using rhythmic solfege) simple sets of rhythms using quarter and eighth note patterns.
Imitate use of solfege syllables (e.g., do, re, mi...) to read short tonal patterns that move up, down, or repeat.
Describe the purpose of notes, staff, and clef signs.
Notate rhythm patterns using traditional notation.
Read (using in rhythmic solfege) sets of simple rhythms that use the quarter rest with quarter, half, and eighth note patterns.
Read (sing) easy melodic patterns using letters (e.g., A, B, C, D, E, F, G) and also using solfege syllables (e.g., do, re, mi, fa, sol, la, si).
Read (using rhythmic solfege) half, quarter, eighth, dotted half, whole notes, and rests.
Read (sing) short melodic patterns that move up and down and repeat using syllables (e.g., do, re, mi, etc.).
Identify symbols (icons/terms) for loud (f - forte) and soft (p - piano).
Read (using rhythmic solfege) and notate whole, half, quarter, eighth, and dotted notes in duple and triple meter signatures.
Read (sing) simple pitch notation in the treble clef in major keys, using a moveable "Do" solfege system of syllables.
Identify symbols and traditional terms referring to dynamics, tempo, and articulation and interpret them correctly when performing.
Recognize major and minor intervals (e.g., major and minor seconds, thirds).
Read (using rhythmic solfege) rhythmic notation, including sixteenth notes, dotted notes, and syncopation (e.g., eighth/quarter/eighth note and eighth-rest/ quarter/eighth note).
Read (sing) melodic notation in treble clef in major keys and minor keys, using solfege.
Use standard symbols to notate meter, rhythm, pitch, and dynamics in song.
Recognize and construct basic chords and chord patterns (e.g., I, V, and V7).
Read and perform rhythmic notation, including quarter-note triplets and tied syncopation.
Read and sing intervals and triads.
Transcribe simple aural examples into rhythmic notation.
Sight-read (sing) melodies in the treble and bass clef.
Recognize and use correct notational symbols for pitch, rhythm, articulation, and dynamics.
Read and perform rhythmic and melodic notation in duple, triple, and mixed meters.
Read and perform intervals, chords, and harmonic progressions.
Transcribe simple aural examples into melodic notation.
Sight-read melodies in the treble and bass clef.
Use standard notation to write down original musical ideas.
Read and perform (using solfege) rhythmic and melodic notation in duple, triple, compound, and mixed meters.
Read and perform augmented and diminished intervals, minor chords, and harmonic minor progression.
Transcribe aural examples into rhythmic and melodic notation.
Use standard notation to write down original musical ideas.
Read an instrumental or vocal score of up to four staves and explain how the elements of music (pitch, rhythm, harmony, dynamics, timbre, texture, form) are used.
Notate simple melodies when presented aurally showing the melodic and rhythmic structure of each (level of difficulty: 1 on a scale of 1-6).
Identify major and minor keys and key changes.
Sight-read music accurately (level of difficulty: 3 on a scale of 1-6).
Read a full instrument or vocal score and explain how the elements of music (pitch, rhythm, harmony, dynamics, timbre, texture, form) are used.
Notate simple melodies when presented aurally showing the melodic and rhythmic structure of each (level of difficulty: 2 on a scale of 1-6).
Identify major and minor keys and key changes, and transpose from one key to another.
Sight-read music accurately (level of difficulty: 4 on a scale of 1-6).
Strand 5: Connect music to other art forms and subject areas through understanding the historical and cultural context of music.
Connect to other subject areas:
Identify different kinds of music that can be heard in daily life.
Participate in activities that explore relationships between music and other arts through drawing, drama, movement, dance, and storytelling.
Participate in music activities that involve sharing, taking turns, and other ways of demonstrating good citizenship.
Describe relationships between music and other arts through drawing, drama, movement, dance, and storytelling.
Use music, together with dance, theatre, and the visual arts, for storytelling.
Count note values/patterns and model properties of numbers.
Explore meaning and relationships of terms that express "rhythm" among the arts (e.g., fast, slow, accent, rhythm patterns, beat, etc.).
Interpret song lyrics/describe sounds of classroom instruments.
Interpret patterns and model properties of numbers.
Explore meaning and relationships of terms that express "melody" among the arts (e.g., melody, theme, subject, line, main idea, etc.).
Develop and use symbolic representations of number patterns.
Identify similarities and differences in the meanings of common terms used in the various arts.
Identify similar themes in stories, songs, and art forms (e.g., patterns, texture).
Identify the use of similar elements in music and other art forms (e.g., form, pattern, rhythm).
Produce sound fundamentals for classroom instruments.
Compare the terminology used for various artistic elements in each of two or more arts.
Explain the role of music in community events and in daily life.
Integrate several art disciplines (dance, music, theatre, or the visual arts) into a well-organized presentation or performance.
Describe how music functions in the media and entertainment industries.
Interpret songs in other languages.
Describe how music is used and adapted for use in film, video, radio, and television.
Explain how elements, artistic processes, and organizational principles are used in similar and distinctive ways in the various art forms.
Identify and research five careers in music that do not involved performing (e.g., producing, managing artists, marketing, copyright law, etc.).
Compare how the characteristic media of two or more arts can be used to transform similar events, scenes, emotions, or ideas into works of art.
Compare and contrast two careers in music that do not involved performing (e.g., producing, managing artists, marketing, copyright law, etc.).
Analyze the process for arranging, underscoring, and composing music for film and video productions.
Connect to history and cultures:
Use appropriate movements to respond to music from various historical periods and cultures.
Sing and play simple singing games from various cultures.
Discuss and interpret characteristics of music heard in the home and community.
Identify family members and friends who sing or play instruments.
Sing songs and play singing games from various cultures.
Listen to/sing music and folk songs of various countries/regions.
Identify roles of musicians in various settings and the uses of specific music in daily or special events.

Name and characterize the use of specific instruments by people of a particular culture (e.g., conga drums and shakers - African & Latino, castanets- Spanish, tom tom drums and bell clusters- Native American).
Interpret holiday songs.
Identify the uses of music in various cultures and time periods.
Listen to a variety of folk music (e.g., American, African, Latin, Asian), identify the artists, and describe their similarities and differences in terms of rhythm, mood, instruments and tone color.
Recognize and talk about music and celebrations of the cultures represented in the school population.
Sing songs and play singing games from various cultures.
Identify and describe roles (past and present) of musicians in and/or from Washington, D.C.
Recognize the influence of various cultures on music in Washington, D.C.
Explain orally or in writing the relationship between music and events in early American history.
Identify various uses of music in their daily experiences and describe characteristics that make certain music suitable for each use.
Explain how experiences, surroundings, stories, and history are expressed through music.

Describe in writing the roles of musicians in each of the four periods of music history (e.g., Baroque, Classical, Romantic and Contemporary) and include a composer and composition representative of each period.
Listen to and identify, by genre or style, examples of music from various historical periods and world cultures.
Describe (orally or in writing) the social functions of a variety of musical forms from various cultures and time periods (e.g., folk songs, dances).
Describe (orally or in writing) the influences of various cultures and historical events on musical forms and styles.
Describe (orally or in writing) distinguishing characteristics of representative composers, musical genres, and styles from two or more cultures.
Compare (orally or in writing) music from two or more cultures of the world as to the functions the music serves and the roles of musicians, including representative composers.
Listen to and describe (orally or in writing) the role of music in ancient and medieval civilizations (e.g., African, Chinese, European, Islamic, Asian, South American).
Compare and contrast musical genres or styles that show the influence of two or more cultural traditions.
Compare, in several cultures of the world, functions music serves, roles of musicians, and conditions under which music is typically created and performed.
Describe (orally or in writing) the influences of various cultures on the music of early United States.
Classify exemplary composers and works of music by style and genre.
Compare and contrast works of music from today and works from the Classical, Baroque, or Romantic periods.
Research the sources of musical genres of the United States, trace the evolution of those genres, and cite well-known musicians associated with them.
Explain the various roles that musicians perform in society (e.g., historical periods, various cultures), providing specific examples of musicians and their achievements.
Describe the differences between styles in traditional folk genres within the United States.
Classify, by genre or style and historical period or culture, unfamiliar but representative aural examples of music and explain the reasoning for the classification.
Describe the means used to create images or evoke feelings and emotions in musical works from various cultures.
Compare and contrast musical styles within various popular genres in North America and South America.
Compare and contrast the social function of a variety of music forms in various cultures and time periods.
Identify uses of music elements in nontraditional art music (e.g., atonal, twelve-tone, serial).
Compare and classify exemplary musical works by genre, style, historical period, composer, and title and explain the characteristics that cause each work to be considered exemplary.
Analyze the stylistic features of a given musical work that define its aesthetic traditions and its historical or cultural context.
Strand 1: Listen to, analyze, and evaluate music.
Beginning
Listen to and analyze music:
Demonstrate the ability to adjust pitch while playing an instrument.
Demonstrate ensemble skills by blending instrumental timbres, matching dynamic levels, responding to basic conducting gestures, and maintaining a steady tempo.
Evaluate Music:
Evaluate individual and group performance by offering suggestions for improvement.
Intermediate
Listen to and analyze music:
Demonstrate the ability to adjust and match pitches.
Demonstrate ensemble skills by blending instrumental timbres; matching dynamic levels, style, and intonation; and responding to conducting gestures.
Evaluate Music:
Evaluate individual and group performance by offering suggestions for improvement.
Proficient
Listen to and analyze music:
Demonstrate the ability to adjust and match pitches.
Demonstrate ensemble skills blending instrumental timbres; matching dynamic levels, style, and intonation; responding to conducting gestures; using conducting gestures.
Evaluate Music:
Diagnose and correct personal performance errors.
Advanced
Listen to and analyze music:
Demonstrate the ability to adjust and match pitches.
Demonstrate ensemble skills blending instrumental timbres; matching dynamic levels, style, and intonation; responding to conducting gestures; using conducting gestures.
Analyze a specific work and discuss how the music elements are used to create expression.
Evaluate Music:
Evaluate and improve personal performance by comparison with an exemplary model.
Strand 2: Sing and perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
Beginning
Sing:
Sing selected lines from the material being studied.
Perform on Instruments:
Demonstrate proper playing position through posture, embouchure and hand position, and proper instrument assembly.
Produce tones that are clear and sustained.
Maintain a steady tempo while performing materials being studied.

Use contrasting articulation:
  • winds: tonguing, slurring
  • strings: dtach, pizzicato, slurring.

Perform four major scales ascending and descending, one octave:
  • winds and percussion: F, Bb, Eb, Ab
  • strings: D, G, C, F.

Perform six (long roll, five stroke roll, nine stroke roll, flam, single paradiddle, ruff) of The Thirteen Essential Rudiments from the National Association of Rudimental Drummers (NARD), open-closeopen (for Percussion students).
Perform a one-octave chromatic scale, ascending and descending (for Wind/Percussion students).
Use dynamic contrast as a means of expression.
Demonstrate musical phrasing (melodic contour, natural accents, use of breath or bow) in materials being studied.
Perform music from a variety of cultures, styles, and historical periods.
Intermediate
Sing:
Sing a part while other students sing contrasting parts.
Perform on Instruments:
Demonstrate proper playing position through posture, embouchure and hand position, and proper instrument assembly.
Produce tones that are clear, free of tension, sustained, and unwavering in pitch.
Incorporate tempo changes and a variety of rhythms and meters in materials being studied.

Demonstrate a variety of articulations or bowings:
  • wind: staccato, legato tongue, accent, marcato, tenuto
  • strings: staccato, brush stroke, hooked bowings, martel, marcato, tremolo, multiple-note slurs.

Perform selected major scales ascending and descending in eighth notes (M.M. quarter note = 72):
  • winds: D, G, C, F, Bb, Eb, Ab, Db
  • violin: C, G, D, A, Bb, Ab, two octaves
  • viola/cello: C, G, D, E, F, Eb, two octaves
  • string bass: C, G, D, A, E, F, Bb, Ab, one octave.
Perform The Thirteen Essential Rudiments from the National Association of Rudimental Drummers (NARD), open-close-open (for Percussion students).
Perform a chromatic scale, ascending and descending, in eighth notes (M.M. quarter note = 72) (for wind/percussion students).

Use dynamic contrast and technical skills as means of expression:
  • winds: vibrato, alternate fingerings, trills, grace notes
  • percussion: multiple mallets and auxiliary instrument techniques, technique on two timpani
  • strings: shifting (violin/viola up to third position; cello/bass up to fourth position), alternate fingerings, vibrato).
Demonstrate musical phrasing through the use of dynamic emphasis and tempo modification in materials being studied.
Perform music from a variety of cultures, styles, and historical periods.
Proficient
Sing:
Sing a part while other students play contrasting parts.
Perform on Instruments:
Demonstrate proper playing position through posture, embouchure and hand position, and proper instrument assembly.
Produce tones that are clear, free of tension, sustained, and unwavering in pitch.
Incorporate tempo changes and a variety of rhythms and meters in materials being studied.

Demonstrate a variety of articulations or bowings:
  • winds: double-tongue, triple-tongue, breath attacks
  • strings: spiccato, sforzando, lour, flautando).

Perform all major scales and selected melodic minor scales with one-octave tonic arpeggios and in thirds, ascending and descending in eighth notes (M.M. quarter note = 72):
  • winds/percussion: e, a, d, g, c, f, b-flat, e-flat
  • violin: g, a, b-flat, c, three octaves
  • viola/cello: c, d, three octaves
  • string bass: e, f, g, two octaves.
Perform The Standard 26 American Drum Rudiments from the National Association of Rudimental Drummers (NARD), open-close-open (for Percussion students).
Perform a chromatic scale, ascending and descending, throughout the practical range of the instrument in sixteenth notes (M.M. quarter note = 72) (for Wind/Percussion students).

Use dynamic contrast and technical skills as a means of expression:
  • winds: vibrato, alternate fingerings, trills, grace notes
  • keyboard percussion: three-mallet technique
  • auxiliary percussion: multiple percussion techniques; timpani technique on 3 to 4
  • timpani: tune drums to reference pitches, make tuning changes within an instrumental work
  • strings: shifting (violin/viola up to fifth position; cello/bass up to thumb position), alternate fingerings, and vibrato.
Demonstrate musical phrasing through the use of dynamic emphasis and tempo modification in materials being studied.
Perform music from a variety of cultures, styles, and historical periods.
Advanced
Sing:
Sing a part while other students sing or play contrasting parts.
Perform on Instruments:
Demonstrate proper playing position through posture, embouchure and hand position, and proper instrument assembly.
Produce tones that are clear, free of tension, sustained, and unwavering in pitch.
Incorporate tempo changes and a variety of rhythms and meters in materials being studied.
Perform all articulations or bowings indicated in materials being studied.
Perform all major and melodic minor scales, selected modes, harmonic minor and pentatonic scales, ascending and descending in a variety of rhythm patterns and articulations.
Perform all of the Percussive Arts Society International Drum Rudiments (Percussive Arts Society), open-close-open.(For Percussion students)
Perform a chromatic scale, ascending and descending, throughout the practical range of the instrument in sixteenth notes (M.M. quarter note = 96) (for Wind/Percussion students).

Use dynamic contrast and technical skills as means of expression varying speeds of vibrato, harmonics, and a variety of timbre effects:
  • winds: embellishments, extreme tessitura, and a variety of timbre effects
  • keyboard percussion: four-and/or six- mallet technique
  • auxiliary percussion: multiple percussion techniques
  • timpani technique on 4 or more drums: tuning all drums to a single reference pitch, make tuning changes within a piece using intervallic pitches
  • strings: shifting (violin/viola 5th position and higher; cello/bass thumb position and above).
Demonstrate musical phrasing through the use of dynamic emphasis and tempo modification in materials being studied.
Perform music from a variety of cultures, styles, and historical periods.
Strand 3: Improvise, arrange, and compose music
Beginning
Embellish two to four measures of a folk song after echoing sample rhythm examples found in folk materials being studied based on I and V (V7) chords.
Compose a two to four measure melody using available technology and teacher specified rhythms and pitches.
Intermediate
Embellish a folk song by creating rhythmic and melodic variations based on I, IV, and V (V7) chords.
Compose an eightmeasure melody using available technology within teacher specified parameters.
Proficient
Improvise a melody to a 12 bar blues and ii-V7-I chord progression.
Harmonize a teacher specified melody using available technology.
Advanced
Improvise a melody to a 12 bar blues, iii-VI-ii-V, and ii-V7-I chord progression in various key centers.
Compose a selection for two or more instruments making use of available technology.
Strand 4: Read and notate music.
Beginning
Sight-read music of varying styles (level of difficulty: 1 on a scale of 1 to 6).
Identify and count rhythm patterns from instructional materials using an established rhythm solfege system.
Identify and define music terms and symbols from materials being studied (e.g., letter names, fingerings or positions, location of notes).
Intermediate
Sight-read music of varying styles (level of difficulty: 2 on a scale of 1 to 6).
Identify and count rhythm patterns from instructional materials using an established rhythm solfege system.
Identify, define, and apply music terms and symbols encountered in the material being studied.
Proficient
Sight-read music of varying styles (level of difficulty: 3-4 on a scale of 1 to 6).
Identify and count rhythm patterns from instructional materials using an established rhythm solfege system.
Identify, define, and apply music terms and symbols encountered in the material being studied.
Advanced
Sight-read music of varying styles (level of difficulty: 5-6 on a scale of 1 to 6).
Identify, count, and analyze rhythm patterns from instructional materials using an established rhythm solfege system.
Identify, define, and apply music terms and symbols encountered in the material being studied.
Strand 5. Connect music to other art forms and subject areas through understanding the historical and cultural context of music.
Beginning
Connect to other subject areas:
Associate terminology common to music with other disciplines.
Identify career options in music.
Connect to history and cultures:
Discuss cultures, styles, composers, and historical periods from materials being studied.
Intermediate
Connect to other subject areas:
Describe concepts common to music and other disciplines.
Identify career and vocational options in music.
Connect to history and cultures:
Discuss cultures, styles, composers, and historical periods from materials being studied.
Proficient
Connect to other subject areas:
Discuss relationships between music concepts and other disciplines.
Research career and vocational options in music using available technology.
Connect to history and cultures:
Compare and contrast materials being studied in its historical and cultural context.
Advanced
Connect to other subject areas:
Analyze concepts common to music and other disciplines.
Research career and vocational options in music using available technology.
Connect to history and cultures:
Associate aural examples of music to a variety of cultures, styles, and historical periods.
Strand 1: Listen to, analyze, and evaluate music.
Beginning
Listen to and analyze music:
Use movement to demonstrate understanding of basic beat and inner rhythm.
Use movement to enhance various styles of music.
Identify similar and contrasting phrases.
Recognize aurally and visually AB and ABA forms.
Evaluate Music:
Create and apply basic criteria for evaluating vocal/choral performances and compositions.
Intermediate
Listen to and analyze music:
Create movement for diverse styles of music.
Analyze four-measure phrases using a symbol system.
Identify monophonic, homophonic, and polyphonic textures.
Recognize aurally and visually AB and ABA forms.
Evaluate Music:
Create and refine criteria for evaluating vocal/choral performances and compositions.
Proficient
Listen to and analyze music:
Create movement for diverse styles of music.
Analyze traditional chord structures in the relationship between voice parts (and accompaniments, if present).
Identify compositional methods in the music being studied, including (but not limited to) fugue, melodic chord patterns, word painting, modulation, and aleatoric music.
Recognize aurally and visually musical form and understand its significance as the structural foundation of most music.
Evaluate Music:
Diagnose and correct personal performance errors.
Advanced
Listen to and analyze music:
Create movement for diverse styles of music.
Analyze traditional and non-traditional chord structures in the relationship between voice parts (and accompaniments, if present).
Identify compositional methods in the music being studied, including (but not limited to) fugue, melodic chord patterns, word painting, modulation, and aleatoric music.
Recognize aurally and visually musical form and understand its significance as the structural foundation of most music.
Apply listening skills to adjust individual intonation within the ensemble.
Evaluate Music:
Evaluate and improve personal performance by comparison with an exemplary model.
Strand 2: Sing and perform on instruments alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
Beginning
Sing:
Respiration:
Use appropriate posture and body alignment to support vocal production.
Identify and describe basic vocal anatomy related to respiration.
Utilize proper breathing techniques while singing.
Phonation/Resonance:
Sing with a free, clear tone, demonstrating accurate intonation.
Use vocal development exercises to produce a relaxed, open sound.
Use vocal development exercises to achieve accurate pitch production.
Sing with purity of vowels, distinguish between vowel sounds, and perform them correctly.
Demonstrate knowledge of basic terminology related to phonation.
Articulation:
Demonstrate clarity of consonants.
Sing in English (and any other languages) in a way that can be understood.
Interpretation:
Demonstrate indicated dynamics and tempo in individual and group singing.
Apply dynamic markings including p, f, mp, mf, pp, ff, crescendo, diminuendo.
Apply tempo markings as indicated.
Performing Literature:
Sing at least three of the following: rounds, canons, descants, partner songs.
Sing literature in two-part harmony.
Sing literature with and without instrumental accompaniment.
Perform music from various world cultures and traditions.
Perform on Instruments:
Use body percussion to practice and perform rhythms.
Identify the musical alphabet and play C, F, and G scales on a piano or keyboard.
Intermediate
Sing:
Respiration:
Use appropriate posture and body alignment to support vocal production.
Demonstrate knowledge of breathing physiology.
Utilize proper breathing techniques while singing.
Phonation/Resonance:
Sing with a free, clear tone, demonstrating accurate intonation.
Use vocal development exercises to produce a relaxed, open sound.
Use vocal development exercises to achieve accurate pitch production.
Sing with purity of vowels, distinguish between vowel sounds, and perform them correctly.
Demonstrate knowledge of basic terminology related to phonation and knowledge of individual singing ranges.
Articulation:
Develop skills in articulation and clarity of pronunciation.
Sing in English (and any other languages) in a way that can be understood.
Interpretation:
Apply dynamic markings consistently.
Demonstrate awareness of blend and balance in choral singing.
Apply tempo markings as indicated.
Performing Literature:
Sing literature in three-part or four-part harmony.
Sing literature with and without instrumental accompaniment.
Perform music from various cultures and traditions.
Perform on Instruments:
Clap melodic rhythm from simple melodies.
Play simple chords and scales on a piano or keyboard.
Proficient
Sing:
Respiration:
Demonstrate understanding of vocal technique and be able to apply it to advanced vocal literature.
Demonstrate knowledge of vocal anatomy.
Exhibit knowledge of breathing physiology and the ability to apply it to singing.
Phonation/Resonance:
Sing with a free, clear tone, demonstrating accurate intonation.
Use vocal development exercises to produce a relaxed, open sound.
Use vocal development exercises to achieve accurate pitch production.
Sing with vowel purity, distinguishing between pure vowel sounds and diphthongs.
Demonstrate the use of vowel placement to adjust tone.
Articulation:
Demonstrate the difference between voiced and unvoiced consonants.
Sing in English (and any other languages) in a way that can be understood.
Interpretation:
Incorporate appropriate mood, dynamics, tempo, and tone color into performance.
Demonstrate blending vocal timbres.
Demonstrate an understanding of phrasing as it effects expression.
Performing Literature:
Perform literature with traditional and nontraditional harmonies and other musical elements.
Sing music in at least four parts, with and without accompaniment.
Perform music from various cultures and traditions in a variety of languages.
Sing in small ensembles with one singer on a part.
Perform on Instruments:
Play an individual voice part on a melodic instrument.
Advanced
Sing:
Respiration:
Demonstrate command of vocal technique and be able to apply it to advanced vocal literature.
Use vocal techniques in the control of dynamics and articulation throughout the vocal range.
Exhibit increased knowledge of breathing physiology and the ability to apply it to singing.
Phonation/Resonance:
Sing with a free, clear tone, demonstrating accurate intonation.
Use vocal development exercises to produce a relaxed, open sound.
Use vocal development exercises to achieve accurate pitch production.
Sing with vowel purity, distinguishing between pure vowel sounds and diphthongs.
Sing acappella music in a variety of keys.
Articulation:
Use the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) as a resource tool.
Sing in English (and any other languages) in a way that can be understood.
Interpretation:
Incorporate appropriate mood, dynamics, tempo, and tone color into performance.
Demonstrate blending vocal timbres and matching dynamic levels.
Demonstrate an understanding of phrasing as it effects expression.
Performing Literature:
Perform literature with complex and non-traditional harmonies and other nontraditional musical elements.
Sing music in at least four parts, with and without accompaniment.
Perform music from various cultures and traditions in a variety of languages.
Sing independently, from memory, a solo from the standard vocal repertoire that is appropriate for an audition.
Perform on Instruments:
Play an accompaniment to a voice part on a melodic instrument.
Strand 3. Improvise, arrange, and compose music
Beginning
Create variations of familiar melodic phrases on a neutral syllable.
Improvise "responses" in a similar style to given rhythmic and melodic phrases.
Compose rhythmic patterns and simple melodies within specified guidelines.
Intermediate
Embellish a folk song by creating rhythmic and melodic variations based on I, IV, and V (V7) chords.
Compose rhythmically interesting melodies within specified guidelines.
Create harmony for a given melody.
Proficient
Improvise a melody to a 12 bar blues and ii-V7-I chord progression.
Compose rhythmically interesting melodies within specified guidelines.
Create harmonies for a given melody.
Advanced
Improvise a melody to a 12 bar blues, iii-VI-ii-V, and ii- V7-I chord progression in various key centers.
Compose a selection for two or more voices making use of available technology.
Strand 4: Read and notate music.
Beginning
Sight-read, analyze and practice simple phrases of up to four measures using music notation.
Intermediate
Sight-read, analyze and practice simple phrases of up to eight measures using music notation.
Read and notate rhythmic patterns in various meters at various tempi.
Proficient
Sight-read individual voice parts in a vocal score.
Use a symbol system to sight-read melodies in major keys.
Read and notate rhythmic and melodic notation.
Advanced
Sight-read individual voice parts in a vocal score.
Use a symbol system to sight-read melodies in major and minor keys.
Read and notate rhythmic and melodic notation.
Strand 5: Connect music to other art forms and subject areas through understanding the historical and cultural context of music.
Beginning
Connect to other subject areas:
Associate common music elements and descriptive terms with those used in art, dance, and drama.
Explore careers in music and relate them to careers in the other fine and performing arts.
Connect to history and cultures:
Compare and contrast the functions of vocal/choral music in various cultures.
Associate distinguishing characteristics of representative choral music from a variety of cultures.
Intermediate
Connect to other subject areas:
Examine and evaluate characteristics of various arts from a particular historic period and various cultures, using appropriate terms.
Explore careers in music and relate them to careers in the other fine and performing arts.
Connect to history and cultures:
Classify an exemplary vocal/choral work by music style.
Describe distinguishing characteristics of representative choral music from a variety of cultures.
Proficient
Connect to other subject areas:
Discuss relationships between music concepts and other disciplines.
Research career and vocational options in music using available technology.
Connect to history and cultures:
Compare and contrast materials being studied in its historical and cultural context, including music from the 20th and/or 21st century.
Advanced
Connect to other subject areas:
Analyze concepts common to music and other disciplines.
Research career and vocational options in music using available technology.
Connect to history and cultures:
Associate aural examples of music to a variety of cultures, styles, and historical periods.
Strand 1: Perform and participate in theatre improvisations and dramatizations to learn acting and scriptwriting fundamentals.
Use dramatic play, costumes, and props to imagine being someone else or something else.
Create characters from familiar stories and life experiences through physical movement, gesture, sound, speech, facial expressions, and emotions.
Work cooperatively to perform an improvisation or dramatize a story.
Retell familiar stories and relate life experiences through ensemble pantomimes and improvisations.
Role-play to recreate situations in familiar settings.
Perform imitative movements, rhythmical activities, and theatre games (e.g., freeze, statues, and mirrors).
Demonstrate the ability to participate cooperatively in performing an improvisation or dramatizing a story.
Improvise familiar simple stories from classroom literature and life experiences with plots that have a beginning, middle, and end.
Use body and voice to improvise alternative endings to a story or concept.
Demonstrate thoughts and feelings through movement.
Demonstrate the ability to work cooperatively in an ensemble to create and present a tableau, an improvisation, or a pantomime.
Retell familiar stories with a focus on specifying character, setting, and conflict through dramatization.
Demonstrate how voice (diction, projection, pace, and mood) may be used to orally present multiple readings of a text.
Respond to voices and language of others through verbal and non-verbal means.
Demonstrate the ability to perform improvisational theatrical games in an ensemble.
Write or improvise a monologue or scene using the five W's (who, what, where, when, and why) that demonstrates the role conflict plays in drama.
Create original scenes based on own experiences or stories, using language and tone of voice appropriate for the person, thing and/or event.
Make acting choices when dramatizing stories, myths, fables, and fairy tales from various cultures and times.
Develop problem-solving and communication skills by participating collaboratively in theatrical experiences.
Demonstrate confidence in discussing theatre vocabulary, activities and performances.
Write or improvise short plays adapted from classroom literature that demonstrate the role conflict plays in drama.
Exemplify the emotional traits of a character through gesture and action.
Make acting choices when dramatizing cultural versions of similar stories from around the world.
Develop problem-solving and communication skills by participating in cooperative scriptwriting that demonstrates knowledge of basic blocking and stage areas.
Demonstrate confidence in creating and presenting performances in the classroom.
Write or improvise scenes based on personal experiences that communicate ideas and feelings.
Create dialogue from personal experience and observation.
Make acting choices when dramatizing scenes from literature that explore universal themes and conflicts.
Develop problem-solving and communication skills by collaborating as an actor or playwright in creating formal or informal theatrical performances.
Demonstrate confidence in creating and presenting performances for an audience.
Write, improvise, and evaluate scenes that reveal character motivation, demonstrate conflict, and advance action
Make acting choices when improvising in a manner that demonstrates an understanding of text, subtext, and context.
Use a variety of vocal expressions, gestures, facial expressions, and timing to create a range of characters.
Create scripts that reflect particular historical periods or cultures.
Write, direct, and perform scenes or short plays that include monologue, dialogue, action, and environment together with a range of character types.
Make acting choices when developing scenes that employ cause and effect, problem-solving, and alternative resolutions to dramatic conflict through the element of plot.
Demonstrate projection, vocal variety, diction, gesture, and confidence in an oral presentation.
Create scripts that include characters, actions, and scenes that exhibit tension and suspense.
Write, improvise, and evaluate scenes that reveal character transformation.
Make acting choices when performing character-based improvisations, pantomimes, or monologues, using voice and gesture to enhance meaning.
Practice variation in pitch, stress, and tempo to convey mood and characterization.
Create short dramatizations with scripts in selected styles of theatre, such as melodrama, comedy, tragedy, and musical theatre.
Write and improvise dialogues and scenes that embody dramatic structure (e.g., exposition, complication, conflict, crisis, climax, and resolution).
Write scenes or plays based on existing scripts, histories, myths, stories, or news events.
Analyze and perform scenes or plays from a variety of theatrical periods and cultural and historical perspectives to determine production requirements.
Make acting choices using script analysis, character research, reflection, and revision through the rehearsal process.
Distinguish facial expression, physicality and gesture based on ones understanding of the character's inner life.
Explore interpersonal relationships among characters through exercises and scenes.
Collaborate on the development of original dramatic pieces leading to performance.

Write a complete theatrical piece (e.g., one-act, 10-minute play, one person show) that embodies dramatic structure and includes complex characters with unique dialogue that motivates the action and explicates the conflict.
Incorporate metaphor, subtext, dramatic themes, and symbolic elements in original monologues and scenes to enhance plot and character.
Design, direct, and perform plays from a variety of theatrical periods and cultural and historical perspectives, including the determination of production requirements.

Make acting choices (e.g., accurate physical mannerisms and dialect) through script analysis and research to create characters from classical, contemporary, realistic, and nonrealistic dramatic texts.
Create gestures, movement qualities, and physical attributes based on one's interpretation and analysis of the inner workings characters.
Demonstrate concepts of space, time, and energy in group improvisations.
Strand 2: Design and manage theatrical environments for formal and informal dramatizations.
Use props to create story elements.
Create costumes and props to dramatize familiar events.
Create costumes, props, and sets to reflect familiar stories.
Identify theatrical conventions, such as props, costumes, masks, and sets.
Use objects and sounds to create appropriate environments.
Create costumes, props, and sets to reflect different characters from literature.
Describe the elements of theater production (e.g., costume, sound, light, set, props, and make-up).
Create environments that communicate locale, character, and mood.
Research, identify and follow instructions to build appropriate props, sets, and costumes for a cultural celebration or pageant.
Explain the roles and responsibilities of the director, actors, and stage managers in the theatre
Demonstrate knowledge of basic blocking and stage areas.
Design and create costumes, props, and makeup/masks to communicate a character in formal and informal theatre performances.
Explain the roles and responsibilities of designers and technical artists in theatre.
Stage scenes or monologues that demonstrate spatial awareness.
Design and select visual and aural elements suitable for character, locale, and situation in formal and informal theatre performances.
Explain the role of the playwright as a collaborating artist with the directors, actors, and designers in the theatre.
Demonstrate the use of blocking (stage areas, levels, and actor's position) in dramatizations.
Analyze a selected scene for technical and design requirements.
Research and create appropriate props, sets, and costumes for a cultural celebration or pageant.
Explain the importance of sets, lights, costumes and sound in communicating dramatic elements to an audience.
Describe characteristics of theatre technology and equipment, including various sound, lighting, and special effects systems.
Analyze and research a play to make design choices about theatrical environments and articulate the rationale for all artistic choices.
Design and create masks, puppets, props, costumes, or sets in a selected theatrical style drawn from world cultures.
Explain how scenery, lighting, sound, costumes and makeup work together to create a theatrical environment.
Demonstrate the ability to participate cooperatively in the different tasks required to create a theatrical production, including assisting with some of the technical equipment of theatre.
Analyze recurring themes and patterns in a script to make production choices in design and direction.
Prepare renderings and sketches for sets and costumes for a short play.
Collaborate as a director or stage manager in creating formal or informal theatrical performances.
Operate available technical equipment in the theater production areas with attention to the safety rules.
Manage time, prioritize responsibilities, and meet completion deadlines for a production as specified by group leader, team members, or directors.
Create designs that use visual and aural elements to convey environments that clearly support the script.
Identify the process of scene, costume, property, lighting, sound, makeup design, construction, and operation in theatrical production.
Collaborate to create functional scenery, properties, lighting, sound, costumes, and makeup by applying technical knowledge and skills.
Analyze a variety of dramatic texts from cultural and historical perspectives to determine production requirements.
Create scenes incorporating sound, music, and voice.
Explain how technology has changed American theatre.
Create rehearsal schedules, set deadlines, organize priorities, and identify needs and resources when participating in the production of a play or scene.
Design production elements for plays from a variety of theatrical periods and cultural and historical perspectives to determine production requirements.
Communicate design and directorial choices to ensemble members using leadership skills, aesthetic judgment, and problem-solving skills.
Collaborate as directors and design team to research, develop, and convey unified production concepts for a performance.
Demonstrate an understanding of the principles of artistic unity, variety, and coherence in visual and aural design and articulate a variety of solutions to design problems.
Perform research and serve as a dramaturge for a play in collaboration with the actors and playwright.
Explain how scientific and technological advances have had an impact on set, light, sound, and costume design, and implementation for the theater.
Strand 3: Analyze, critique, and respond to theatre and dramatic media.
Make specific observations of people, places and things.
Respond appropriately as an audience member.
Use the vocabulary of theatre, such as perform, imagination, movement, audience, actor, character, cooperation, ensemble and environment to describe theatrical experiences.
Distinguish between a performance space and an audience space, and respond appropriately to a theatrical experience as an audience member.
Use the vocabulary of the theatre, such as play, plot (beginning, middle, and end), playwright, improvisation, and stage, to describe theatrical experiences.
Identify and discuss emotional reactions to a theatrical experience and describe the roles and responsibilities of audience and actor.
Observe and respond to actors' performances.
Use the vocabulary of theatre, such as monologue, dialogue, scene, design, and script, to describe theatrical experiences.
Respond to a live performance by identifying its style (e.g., comedy, tragedy, musical) and describe its impact on the audience.
Respond to and describe an actor's use of voice, gesture, facial expression, and movement.
Use the vocabulary of theatre, such as character, setting, costumes, props, stage areas, and blocking to describe theatrical experiences.
Respond to a work of theatre and explain either orally or in writing how the actors and playwright elicited that response.
Identify a character's objectives and motivations in stories/short plays to explain that character's feelings and behavior.
Use the vocabulary of theatre, such as plot, conflict, climax, tone, objectives, motivation, and theme to describe theatrical experiences.
Describe how actors convey meaning or intent, including relationships between characters (conflict and resolution).
Identify themes by analyzing major ideas of stories/short plays.
Use the vocabulary of theatre, such as stage manager, cue, director, critic, protagonist, and antagonist to describe theatrical experiences.
Compare the content or message in two different works of theatre, including the visual and aural elements used to create character, locale, and situation in each.
Identify and relate to universal characters, themes, or morals in stories/short plays from different periods and places.
Use the vocabulary of theatre, such as action/reaction, vocal projection, subtext, theme, mood, design, production values and stage crew, to describe theatrical experiences.
Analyze the use of figurative language and imagery to create tone and mood in dramatic texts.
Identify dramatic elements within a script, such as foreshadowing, crisis, rising action, catharsis, and denouement, using the vocabulary of theatre.
Explain how a dramatic performance on video or film depicts a feeling or event the student may have experienced.
Develop criteria and write a formal review of a theatrical performance, using basic theatre terminology.
Use the vocabulary of theatre, such as playwright, rehearsal, dress rehearsal, run-through, and cold-reading to describe theatrical experiences.
Evaluate variation in pitch, stress, and tempo to convey mood and characterization in theatre productions.
Critique design elements of theatre productions as they relate to tone, mood, time, and place.
Explore the theatrical elements of a ritual within a culture that marks a "rite of passage".
Develop criteria and write a formal review of a theatrical production incorporating elements such as script, actors, design, and direction.
Use the vocabulary of theatre, such as ensemble, proscenium, thrust, and arena staging to describe theatrical experiences.
Analyze short dramatizations in selected styles of theatre, such as melodrama, comedy, tragedy, and musical theatre.
Critique the design elements of a performance (e.g., sets, lights, costumes, sound) relative to how they communicate the playwright's intentions and meaning.
Discuss responses to a theatrical performance explaining what ideas and feelings were conveyed and why the audience may have sympathized or was displeased with the main character.
Develop criteria and create a formal review of a theatrical production that analyzes the themes of the play.
Use the vocabulary of theatre, such as style, genre, design, and theme to describe theatrical experiences.
Compare a traditional interpretation of a play with a nontraditional interpretation and defend the merits of each.
Document observations and perceptions on how a specific actor used theatre techniques to convey meaning in his or her performances.
Identify key figures, works, and trends in world theatrical history from various cultures and time periods.
Identify how a playwright utilizes character, dialogue, environment, and time as well as elements of spectacle, sound, and music to develop a script.
Use complex evaluation criteria and appropriate terminology to compare and contrast theatrical productions in a variety of genres (e.g., comedy, tragedy, musical).
Use the vocabulary of theatre, such as genre, style, theme, and design to analyze theatrical experiences.
Assess the intent, structure, and quality of informal and formal theatre productions.
Document observations and perceptions of production elements of a play, noting mood, pacing, and use of space.
Compare and contrast specific styles and forms of theatre such as naturalism, expressionism, and theatre of the absurd.
Evaluate the relevance of scripts using both adapted and original material.
Compare treatments of the same play by different directors, designers, or theatre companies.

Read a review of a local theatre production analyzing the critic's writing style, approach to priorities in the production, and conclusions about the play in performance, discussing the points of agreement and disagreement.
Strand 4: Apply theatrical concepts to construct meaning and understanding in other subject areas.
Identify differences between real and imaginary characters, stories and places.
Use movement and voice to reinforce vocabulary (e.g., fast/slow, in/on/through, over/under, big/little, loud/soft).
Apply the theatrical concept of beginning, middle, and end to other content areas.
Dramatize a story or a current event from another subject area.
Identify various theatrical experiences, including live theatre, television, and puppetry.
Use body, voice, and imagination to illustrate concepts in other content areas.
Compare and contrast how live theatre differs from filmed or taped performances.
Use improvisation and dramatization to explore concepts in other content areas.
Interpret how theatre and storytelling forms (past and present) of various cultural groups may reflect their beliefs and traditions.
Use theatrical skills to dramatize events from other curriculum areas (e.g., reenacting the signing of the Declaration of Independence).

Use theatrical skills to identify and communicate rhetorical ideas from other curriculum areas (e.g., demonstration on persuasion and propaganda in advertising).

Explain how cultural influences affect the content or meaning of works of theatre.

Compare and contrast a traditional interpretation of a play with an innovative interpretation.
Describe the ways in which playwrights reflect and influence history and culture with emphasis on American playwrights.
Analyze the influence of traditional and nontraditional theatre, film, television, and electronic media on values and behaviors.
Compare and contrast a traditional and innovative interpretation of a play.
Create projects using tools, techniques, and processes from the study and practice of theatre, film/video, and electronic media to advance understanding of other subject areas.

Distinguish between 2-dimensional shapes and 3- dimensional forms (e.g., circle vs. sphere, square vs. cube).
