Distinguish among various media (e.g., clay, paints, drawing materials) when looking at works of art, including his/her own.
Describe and replicate lines that show movement in figures and nature.
Identify the elements of art -line, color, shape, form, and texture in objects in the environment and works of art.
Distinguish between circle, square, triangle, rectangle, oval, and organic free-form shapes. Visit a local art museum to see shapes and original works of art.
Distinguish between sphere, cube, cylinder, cone, and forms of objects in nature.
Find, describe and replicate visual rhythms seen in nature, the environment, and works of art.
Perceive and discuss the use of lines to represent objects in the environment
Perceive and discuss differences in mood created by warm and cool colors.
View public (outdoor) sculpture and determine what the artist was trying to express.
Identify and name basic spatial relationships of objects seen in nature, the environment, and works of art, using art vocabulary: overlapping, foreground and background.
Identify and name color, line, shape, form, and texture seen in nature, the environment, and works of art based on a museum/gallery visit.
Find, describe and replicate visual rhythms and balance in nature, in the environment, and in works of art
Describe elements of art in works of art, emphasizing line, color, shape, form, texture, space, and value.
Identify the elements of art in students' own art work
Describe how artists use tints and shades in painting.
Describe how the illusion of 3-D objects are depicted in 2-D works of art.
Identify and describe how foreground, middle ground, and background are used to create the illusion of space.
Identify and describe a contour drawing of an object found in the environment.
Compare and contrast two works of art made by the use of different art tools and media (e.g., watercolor, tempera, and computer).
Perceive and describe rhythm and movement in works of art, in nature and the environment.
Name criteria of quality design.
Identify and describe representational, abstract and non-representational works of art.

Distinguish between representational and nonrepresentational sculpture seen on a visit to museums such as the Sculpture Gardens of the National Gallery of Art and the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden.

Identify various types of lines (e.g., straight/curved, thick/thin, long/short, vertical/horizontal/diagonal, contour, ruled lines, calligraphy, and other freehand studies from observation, imagination, and schematic studies).

Describe and analyze the elements of art, (e.g., line, color, shape, form, texture, space, and value) emphasizing form, as they appear in nature, the environment and works of art found in the classroom, in art reproductions, in students' own work, during online research, or a museum visit, such as the Corcoran Gallery of Art.
Identify, name and describe negative shapes and forms and positive shapes and forms seen in a selected work of art.
Differentiate between visual and actual textures using objects in nature, the environment and works of art
Identify pairs of complementary colors (e.g. yellow/violet; red/green; blue/orange) and discuss how artists use them to communicate an idea or mood
Perceive and describe contrast and emphasis in works of art, nature and in the environment.
Identify criteria of quality design
Identify and describe a gesture drawing found in a work of art.

Discuss the style and techniques used to create portraits of the U.S. colonial and American Revolutionary heroes that can be seen at Art museums such as the National Portrait Gallery and/or the National Gallery of Art.
Use knowledge of all the elements of art to analyze similarities and differences in works of art and in the environment.
Analyze and describe why and how value and contrast are used by artists to create shading as they appear in nature, the environment and works of art.
Identify and describe how foreground, middle ground, background, and overlapping are used to create the illusion of space
Identify and describe works of art using one-point perspective.
Identify, name, and describe the principles of design in visual compositions, emphasizing unity and harmony
Distinguish and describe the concept of proportion (e.g. in face, figure) and scale used in works of art.
Discuss the style and techniques used to create images of Industrial America and 20th century heroes that can be seen at art museums such as the Smithsonian American Art Museum.
Identify criteria of quality design.
Identify and describe the differences between contour and gesture drawing.
Perceive and explain how artists create unity and harmony in assemblage sculpture which can be seen at art museums such as the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden or the Corcoran Gallery of Art.
Develop a working understanding of line drawing techniques. Interpret the technical characteristics of a drawing such as the convexity, specificity, technical qualities, and axis.
Discuss the technique of implied line, value contrasts, and variations of value to provide shape identification and visual separation of objects.

Identify and discuss works of art including the subject, theme, genre, style, function, and differences in media. Describe how an artist can use the same theme in a work of art using different media and style resulting in a different effect.
Describe the differences between two and three-dimensional visual fields.
Identify one point perspective and how artists use value, light and shadow to show emphasis in perspective drawings.
Describe how balance is effectively used in work of art (e.g., symmetrical, asymmetrical, radial).

Visit a museum to identify examples of balance through symmetry, (e.g. Henri Matisse, Large Composition with Masks (National Gallery of Art), Eiffel Tower, Brooklyn Bridge, Islamic tilework; M.C. Escher; and asymmetry, e.g. Chinese landscapes (Freer/Sackler), Edgar Degas, Four Dancers (NGA*)
Visit museum /gallery to study figurative sculpture, (e.g. Northwest Native American masks, Tlingit, Kwakiutl, Yup'ik Eskimo, National Museum of the American Indian).
Identify and describe examples of art that shapes the natural environment (e.g. gardens, eco-design, etc.).

Recognize contemporary technology in works of art (e.g., color fills on computers, texture methods on computers, fonts/point systems, animation techniques, video teleconferencing, multimedia techniques). View artists examples, e.g., Nam June Paik, video artist, (SAAM); Hayao Miyazaki, animated filmmaker.
Identify drawing media (e.g. charcoal, conte' crayon, pen and ink) and discuss how different media are used to achieve different effects.
Analyze various shading techniques used by artist (e.g. hatching, crosshatching, blending, and stippling) in drawings.
Identify, name, and describe scale and proportion as applied to two-dimensional and three-dimensional works of art.
View and describe ways subject matter is depicted.
Introduce the rules of 2 point perspective in comparison to 1 point perspective in drawings.
Develop a working understanding of line drawing techniques. Interpret the technical characteristics of a drawing, such as proportion and internal ratios.

Describe the ways in which artists convey the illusion of space (e.g., placement, overlapping, relative size, atmospheric, and linear perspective). View the art of Jacob Lawrence, Maurice Prendergast, and Honor Daumier at The Phillips Collection.
Search the internet to identify and compare how artists create the illusion of space in a variety of art works.
Visit a museum/gallery to view work of the Washington Color School. (e.g. Corcoran Gallery, National Gallery)

Interpret reality and fantasy in original two-dimensional and three-dimensional works of art. Visit the National Gallery of Art and discuss Renee Magritte and a Salvador Dali style at the National Museum of African Art.
Analyze how real objects are created from 3-D forms such as sphere, cone, cube, cylinder, pyramids and their variation or combinations.
Use and identify hues, values, intermediate shades, tints, tones, complimentary, analogous, and monochromatic colors.
Observe and explain how artists create unity and harmony in assemblage sculpture seen at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden.
Explain criteria of quality aesthetic design
Develop a working understanding of line drawing techniques. Interpret the technical characteristics of a drawing, such as continuity, regularity and structure.
Describe how different values of a color can affect meaning in artworks.
Analyze how scale is used in developing a drawing.
Analyze the use of the elements of art and the principles of design as they relate to meaning in video, film, or electronic media.
Visit museum/gallery to identify, analyze and compare how artists use color.
Research film, photography, computer graphics, and/or video to describe the making of works of art. Describe artists examples such as Nam June Paik, (Smithsonian American Art Museum).
Distinguish between types and expressive qualities of line. Analyze Jacob Lawrence's The Migration Series at The Phillips Collection
Compare and contrast the concept of visual field in relation to shape and form.
Explain and demonstrate basic and complex shapes through convexity, specificity and axis.
Analyze systems of visualizing information and depicting space and volume (e.g., scale, vanishing point, linear, atmospheric, and isometric perspective); and create works using these systems.

Describe and analyze the way the elements of art - color, value, and texture are used to convey an intended concept based on works of art found in the classroom, in art reproductions, in students' own work, during online research, or a museum visit.
Write a critique of art that demonstrates use of the elements and principles of design in establishing a point of view, a sense of space and mood.
Analyze the principles of design as used in works of art.

Analyze and describe how the composition of a work of art is affected by the use of a particular principle of design (e.g. balance, unity, contrast, emphasis, proportion, pattern, movement, rhythm, harmony, variety).
Study a specific work of art in a museum/gallery and provide a critical analysis of the visual statement in terms of the elements and principles of design.
Explain criteria of quality aesthetic design.
Research and analyze the work of an artist and write about the artist's distinctive style and its contribution to the meaning of the work.
Analyze works of art influenced by historical and cultural events utilizing an expanded art vocabulary
Analyze complex ideas, such as distortion, color theory, arbitrary color, scale, expressive content, and real versus virtual in works of art, including in series of their original works of art.
Analyze students' original works of art, explaining in detail their personal direction and style, including the use of elements to express mood in one or more of their works of art.
Analyze and interpret works of art from various societies using sophisticated art historical and culturally specific vocabulary.
Create artwork that demonstrates facility with elements and principles of design to establish a personal style.

Based on a museum visit, research two periods of painting, sculpture, film, or other media and discuss their similarities and differences, using the language of the visual arts in written paper and oral presentation.
Compare how distortion is used in photography or video with how the artist uses distortion in painting and sculpture.
Impact of Media Choice
Based on a museum visit, analyze the media used by a given artist and describe how its use influences the meaning of the work.
Compare and contrast similar styles of works of art using electronic and non-traditional media with media traditionally used in the visual arts.
Select works of art from students' portfolio and discuss the intent of the work and the use of the media.

Based on a museum visit, analyze the works of a well-known artist. Discuss the art media selected and the effect of that selection on the artist's style. Select a work of the artist in another medium and compare the effect.
Explain the role and influence of new technologies on contemporary works of art.
2. Apply artistic processes and skills in a variety of media to communicate meaning and intent in original works of art. (Production and Creative Expression)
Skills, Processes, Materials, and Tools
Create works of art using a variety of media and materials (e.g., pencils, crayons, paints, stamps, paper, and clay).
Experiment with using several colors through the use of a variety of drawing materials and paints
Create two-dimensional patterns and three-dimensional arrangements (using manipulatives or blocks).
Use materials and tools safely.
Assemble a collage with cut or torn paper shapes.
Use basic geometric shapes to create an image of a person
Create symmetrical, patterned and random arrangements using lines, shapes, forms, and colors.
Create three-dimensional constructions using basic tools and art processes, such as paper and foam products, scissors, and glue.
Draw a person using a variety of lines and shapes to show movement (e.g., bending parts).
Create two-dimensional and three-dimensional works of art using both real and visual textures.
Mix secondary colors from primary colors and describe the process.
Use basic tools and art-making processes, such as printing, crayon-rubbings, collage, and stencils.
Create a contour drawing of shapes.
Express personal thoughts and feelings using both warm and cool colors.
Create artworks using art media such as oil pastels, watercolors, and tempera paint.
Create an illustration of your family using 2-dimensional visual field (e.g., large to small size relationships).
Create form and texture in works of art using clay, paper, papier mach, and fibers.
Create a contour drawing of shapes.
Mix and apply tempera paints to create tints, shades, and neutral colors.
Use fibers or other materials to create simple weaving. Visit museums such as the Textile Museum.
Experiment with digital technologies to create art (e.g., CDs, computer software, digital photography).
Create an illustration of people using 3-dimensional visual field (e.g., overlapping or foreground, middle ground, and background).
Maintain the workspace, materials, and tools responsibly and safely.
Create a contour drawing of objects showing convexity.
Use shading (value) to transform a two-dimensional shape into what appears to be a three-dimensional form (e.g., circle to sphere).
Create a self portrait using proportional size relationships.
Draw people in proportion to objects found in nature or in their environment.
Work with contemporary technologies (e.g., internet access, library computer card catalogues) to create art.
Maintain the workspace, materials, and tools responsibly and safely.
Create gesture and contour observational drawings demonstrating horizontal axis, vertical axis and diagonal axis.
Use one-point perspective to create the illusion of space (e.g., hallway, railroad).
Draw a figure study using the conventions of facial and figure proportions.
Experiment with digital imagery (e.g., computer-generated art, digital photography, or videography).
Maintain the workspace, materials, and tools responsibly and safely.
Apply the rules of one-point perspective in creating a thematic work of art (e.g. landscape)
Use curved lines to create a symmetrical and/or asymmetrical drawing using implied and overlapping lines.
Use varying values of tints, shades, and intensities when drawing(e.g. portraits, still life, landscapes) to define form
Maintain the workspace, materials, and tools responsibly and safely.

Apply the rules of 2- point perspective to show the illusion of depth on a two-dimensional surface, using overlapping shapes, relative size, and placement within the picture (e.g. landscape, cityscape).
Use scaled proportion in a drawing of forms (e.g., cube, cylinder, cone, and pyramid).
Use various shading methods in a drawing to show light and shadow (e.g. hatching, crosshatching, stippling, and blending).
Mix paints and show color relationships.
Using congruent triangles and area measurement create a patterned design (e.g. quilt)
Maintain the workspace, materials, and tools responsibly and safely.
Use variations or combinations of basic three dimensional forms (e.g. cube, cone, cylinder, sphere, pyramid) to draw or paint realistic objects (e.g., vase, pitcher, bed, automobile).
Demonstrate technical skills in using complex two-dimensional art media and processes such as the printing press and silk screening.
Use various observational drawing skills to depict a variety of subject matter, to include sculpture, outdoors or in museum.
Create a 3-D scale model using surface area and volume.
Maintain the workspace, materials, and tools responsibly and safely.
Illustrate images that demonstrate use of light and shadow, texture, reflection, and transparency
Draw simple and complex three-dimensional objects demonstrating size, proportion, placement, linear perspective, and non-linear methods.
Illustrate designs of spaces and places (e.g. architectural, commercial and recreational spaces) in freehand or using computer software.
Design computer generated graphics for advertising and informational products in print or virtual (e.g., the layout of covers, posters, brochures, web sites).
Use electronic technology for reference and for creating original work, including the manipulation of digital imagery (either still or video).
Produce industrial designs (e.g., product, packaging, furniture, appliances, transportation, clothing, automotive).

Prepare a portfolio of original two and three-dimensional works of art that reflects refined craftsmanship and technical skills, and shows knowledge of unique characteristics of particular media, materials, and tools.
Assemble and display objects or works of art as a part of a public exhibition.
Demonstrate the effective and safe application of materials, equipment, and tools during the production of works of art.
Render subtle differences of light and shadow, reflection, transparency, and utilize implied texture in solving drawing and painting problems.
Explore a single subject through a series of works that demonstrates a variety of media and mastery of materials, techniques and tools.
Create works of art that demonstrate use of local value, variations, irradiation, and aerial perspective
Plan and create works of art that reflect complex ideas, such as distortion, color theory, arbitrary color, scale, expressive content, and real versus virtual
Prepare floor plan and construct miniature building based on analysis and study of ancient buildings, obelisks, monuments, statues, and other architectural forms.

Skillfully apply traditional technologies (e.g., relief printing, acid printing, etching methods) and contemporary technologies (e.g., virtual reality design, photographic tools, broadcast equipment, film cameras, preservation tools, web graphics, computer generated designs) best suited to intended effect or impact.
Identify potential health hazards associated with materials and techniques, and possible substitutes for hazardous materials.
Expression Through Original Works of Art
Create an image representing a person using lines and shapes (e.g., stick figure).
Use several different materials to express several different feelings (e.g. joy, sadness, surprise) about life experiences, such as family events, birthdays, holidays, play, sudden events.
Create and discuss personal artwork made in response to literature.
Express ideas about family and neighborhood using paint.
Create three-dimensional forms (e.g., a real or imaginary animal) using clay and other workable media.
Use overlapping in a collaged still life composition.
Create two-dimensional artwork based upon observations of everyday scenes and in response to literature.
Create three-dimensional artwork actual of actual objects using clay, paper and other media.
Plan and use variations in line, shape/form, color, and texture to communicate ideas or feelings in works of art.
Represent people, animals and buildings with sculptural materials.
Create two and three-dimensional expressive artwork that explores abstraction using line, shape, color, and texture.
Create visual balance using line and rotational symmetry.
Create still life and genre paintings.
Show the illusion of space by using a background, foreground and overlapping objects in a two-dimensional painting or drawing (e.g., landscape, seascape, or cityscape).
Create a work of art based on the observation of objects and scenes in daily life, emphasizing value changes.
Create an imaginative clay sculpture based on an organic form.
Use a printing process to create an original work of art emphasizing rhythm and movement.
Use the interaction between positive and negative space in a works of art.
Create a portrait demonstrating personality or a figure drawing or painting, using proportional size relationships.
Use additive and subtractive processes in making sculptural forms.
Use complementary colors in an original compositional to show contrast (light and dark) and emphasis.
Create an expressive abstract composition based on real objects using line characteristics (e.g. straight/curved. thick/thin/zigzag).
Draw a landscape showing foreground, middle ground and background using overlapping to demonstrate perspective in a real or an imaginary scene.
Use the principles of unity and harmony to create an assemblage (a found object sculpture) or a mixed media two-dimensional composition that communicates a universal theme.
Communicate values, opinions, and/or personal insights in an original work of art.
Select specific media and processes to express moods, feelings, themes, or ideas.
Design and create an expressive figurative sculpture.
Use contemporary technology to create original works of art (e.g., color and texture methods on computers, fonts/point systems, animation techniques, video teleconferencing, multimedia techniques).
Select a medium to use to communicate a theme in a series of works of art.
Create a genre painting.
Illustrate reality and fantasy in a work of art.
Create symmetrical designs using rotation, reflection and/or translation shapes on a measured grid.
Use contemporary technologies to create original works (e.g., film, photography, computer graphics, or video).
Select a drawing medium (e.g., pencil, pen and ink, marker) to create a scaled up version of a painting from a chosen artist.
Design a work of public art appropriate to and reflecting a location, (e.g., a Metro station.)
Design and create maquettes (small scale crafted models) for three-dimensional public sculptures for specific locations in Washington.
Combine film, photography, computer graphics, and/or video to create an original work of art. Describe artists' examples, such as Nam June Paik at the Smithsonian American Art Museum.
Solve a visual arts problem that involves the effective use of the elements of art and the principles of design.
Create an expressive composition, focusing on unity, e.g., dominance and subordinate.
Create a two or three-dimensional work of art that addresses a social theme.
Demonstrate a personal style that communicates an idea, theme, or emotion in a series of compositions.
Use innovative visual metaphors and develop a distinct visual vocabulary in creating a work of art.
Present a universal concept in a multimedia or mixed media work of art.
Analyze and discuss art which demonstrates expressiveness of media.
Create artwork that consistently demonstrates an advanced knowledge of the elements and principles of design in expressing personal style.

3. Investigate and understand historical and cultural dimensions of the visual arts and to construct meaning in the diverse ways in which human experience is expressed across time and place. (Historical and Cultural Context)
Historical Development, Role and Cultural Diversity of the Visual Arts
Identify and describe art objects in daily life.
Describe pictorial objects that appear in works of art.
Identify and describe activities in works of art that show people doing things together.
Discuss and ask questions about art objects from various cultures in Washington, DC using art reproductions and online sources.
Recognize symbols used to represent the United States (e.g., the American flag with stars and stripes, the bald eagle).
Identify images of self, friends, and own family (including photographs and student's own work).
Observe, describe and classify examples of local architecture and public spaces (e.g. houses, schools, parks).
Describe functional and non-utilitarian art seen in daily life, (e.g., works of art that are used versus those that are for viewing).
Recognize, describe, and discuss American and international flags and symbols.

Investigate everyday objects from various time periods and cultures by comparing and contrasting them with objects students recognize from their daily lives (e.g. ceramic mug from US and ceramic tea bowl from Japan).
Identify and describe works of art that show people working and living together (genre paintings or sculpture).
Identify, describe, and discuss the meaning of visual elements and symbols of holidays, birthdays, and/or cultural events (e.g. birthday candles, piatas, menorahs).
Identify and describe real-life subject matter in landscapes, seascapes, cityscapes, portraits, still lifes, and scenes of everyday life. Examples can be viewed at The Phillips Collection.

Identify and describe the artwork of Maya, Inca, Aztec, European American, and traditional African cultures, exploring the role of artists and how art objects were understood in cultural contexts. Examples can be found at local art museums.
Recognize, list and pose relevant questions about important monuments from various time periods in North America.
Articulate how artists use their work to share experiences and/or express ideas, comparing and contrasting specific examples.
Describe the function and meaning of specific art objects from Africa. African art can be viewed at the Smithsonian's National Museum of African Art.
Discuss how art is used in events and celebrations in American culture, past and present, and relate to objects used for similar events and celebrations in other cultures.

Explain how cultures have used design to communicate ideas. Artist examples can be viewed at the Museum of the American Indian, the Smithsonian museums, such as the Anacostia Museum, the Sackler/ Freer Galleries or the National Museum of African Art.
Compare and describe various works of art that have a similar theme and were created at different time periods.
Identify artists from his or her own community and discuss local or regional art traditions.
Identify basic styles of art from student's own cultural background and other parts of the world.
Compare and contrast the different purposes for which people of different cultures create art.
Describe the function and meaning of specific works of art and objects from the Pacific Islands.

Explore and form an opinion about public art and design in the neighborhood, such as monuments, parks, plazas, murals, buildings, and bridges. Explain how these structures contribute to the cultural life of the neighborhood.
Identify and discuss works of art from different cultures that contribute to the history and art heritage of the District of Columbia.

Identify and discuss the Classical (Greco-Roman) influences in the monuments and special buildings of the Federal Government in Washington, DC Which can be seen in art museums such as the Corcoran Gallery of Art.
Articulate how art and artifacts play a role in reflecting early Native American life (e.g. in photography, quilts, architecture).
Describe the function and meaning of works of art and objects from Europe. View Impressionist, post-Impressionist, and non-representational artists at The Phillips Collection.
Describe an historic district observing the architecture and landscape; speculate how it has changed since its original construction.
Describe a local historical house, sharing observations about how the structure and the objects in it present a picture of life in another era.
Compare and contrast art objects that have a similar theme from different part of the world observed in visits to museums or galleries (e.g., puppets, masks, containers).
Identify and discuss the content of works of art in the past and present, focusing on the different cultures that have contributed to the District of Columbia's history and art heritage.
Research and describe the influence of religious groups' history on art and architecture, focusing primarily on buildings in the District of Columbia both past and present.
Identify and describe how a person's own cultural content influences responses to works of art. Create a composition that illustrates a personal cultural celebration.
Describe, compare, and contrast various depictions of the American West, posing relevant questions about the perspectives of the artists.
Identify and describe examples of African-American art and architecture, explaining how African-American artwork reflects multicultural West African and European-American art and societies.
Compare and contrast images of industrialization, discussing how they celebrate or criticize its impact.
Relate six works in the arts chronologically to historical events (e.g., 10,000 B.C. to present)

Identify and compare works of American art and architecture that show regional differences. View and discuss original examples that can be seen at a major local art museum, such as the National Building Museum, the Smithsonian American Art Museum or the Corcoran Art Gallery.
Analyze the visual languages used in the fine art, advertising and propaganda of the World War II era.
Identify and describe how various cultures define and value art differently
Research the role of visual art and arts during the Harlem Renaissance, exploring how visual arts reflect society and relate to other art forms (e.g. music, dance & theatre).
Identify the characteristics and purposes of works of world art in historical and cultural contexts.
Describe the various ways that ethnic groups in the U.S., world regions and countries, understand and value art and design.
Describe the function and meaning of specific works of art and objects from Asia.
Describe how selected works of art from ethnic groups in selected world regions and countries have changed or not changed in theme and content over a period of time.
Demonstrate a fundamental awareness of architectural styles and the ways that these have influenced painting and sculpture.
Compare, in oral or written form, representative images or designs from at least two selected cultures, to identify universal symbols and themes, based on museum internet research or a museum visit.
Describe the influence of religious groups' history on art and architecture, focusing primarily on buildings in the District of Columbia both past and present.
Describe the main function and meaning of works of art from Ancient Civilizations and the Middle East (e.g., ancient Greece, the Persian Empire, Egypt, Rome, India, China, and the Silk Road).
Relate works in the arts chronologically to historical events (e.g., 10,000 B.C to present), including a graphic benchmark timeline.
Participate in a DC sponsored art event; recognize how painting a mural or reclaiming a public space helps to transform a neighborhood and improves the quality of life.
Research and describe how art and architecture can reflect cultural values in traditions throughout the world.

Relate works of art to varying styles and genres to the periods in which they were created (e.g., Bronze Age, Ming Dynasty, Renaissance, Classical, Modern, Post-Modern, Contemporary, Futuristic, others). Use museum internet research and museum observation for research.
Explain how objects made for functional, ritual, and other purposes are considered art in different contexts.
Compare, contrast, and analyze styles of art from a variety of early, colonial and contemporary America, drawing on a museum visit and research.
Explain the function and meaning of works of art from its historical perspective.
Examine and report on the role of a work of art created to make social comment or protest social conditions. The works of Jacob Lawrence and Honore Daumier can be viewed at The Phillips Collection.

Investigate the origin and/or preservation history of a historic site, a subway station, or public work of art through a site visit. Recognize how artists/designers can change the public's perception of a space.

Discuss the artistic contributions of various native and immigrant cultures in the United States (e.g., Native American, German, Irish, Italian, African, Caribbean, Mexican). Artworks can be seen at museums such as the Corcoran Gallery of Art.
Identify and discuss the classical influences in the monuments and special buildings of the Federal Government in Washington, DC.

Identify the message of major works of art created by women during identified times. Describe the societal impact of those works. Utilize internet research and site visits (e.g., Primary sources can be viewed at the National Museum of Women in the Arts).

Identify contemporary artists of merit worldwide who have achieved regional, national, or international recognition and discuss ways in which their works reflect, play a role in, and influence present-day culture. Perform online research by visiting museum Web sites.

Identify examples of historic and contemporary masterpieces associated with global regions, across a range of styles, periods, symbols, iconography, subject matter, materials, and techniques. (e.g., African, Asian, Caribbean, Europe, Mexican, Latino, Middle Eastern, Native-American, and Pacific Asian).
Discuss the similarities and differences between several comparable works of art from the same cultural domain (region or ethnicity) across long durations of time (centuries).
Identify an architectural structure/form in a world culture and analyze its relationship to the culture and the environment.

Identify and describe trends in the visual arts and discuss how the issues of time, place, and cultural influence are reflected in selected works of art (e.g., Explore the period of the Harlem Renaissance during the 1920's and 1930's. Trace the development of cultural awareness throughout the African Diaspora). Use examples from Washington, DC museums.

Discuss the purposes of art in selected classical and contemporary cultures. (e.g., African/African-American, Asian/Asian-American, Caribbean, Europe/European-American, Hispanic/Latino-American, Middle Eastern, Native-American, and Pacific Asian).
Identify contemporary styles and discuss the diverse social, economic, and political developments reflected in the works of art examined. Visit a major local museum to see original examples.
Discuss the similarities and differences between several comparable works of art from the same cultural domain (region or ethnicity) across long durations of time (centuries).
Categorize and distinguish artistic styles of the late 19th, 20th and 21st centuries in terms of purpose, interpretive approach and historical context.

Recognize major historic and contemporary masterpieces associated with global regions, taking into consideration styles, periods, symbols, iconography, subject matter, materials, and techniques. (e.g., African, Asian, Caribbean, Europe, Mexican, Latino, Middle Eastern, Native- American, and Pacific Asian).

Identify and demonstrate how a historic and cultural idea has been represented and has changed or remained static over time and location (e.g., Egyptian Pharonic sculpture; representations of Buddha; the human figure in European art).

Compare and contrast architectural structures that serve similar purposes from different parts of the world. Demonstrate how geography and culture have an impact on choice of materials, design, and aesthetic qualities of these structures.
Investigate and discuss universal concepts expressed in works of art, articulating the various ways (both similar and different) through which these concepts are expressed across diverse cultures.
Research the methods art historians use to determine the time, place, context, value, and culture that produced a given work of art.
Examine artworks of world culture with regard to major periods of art from the ancient era to early modern times, and genres from various geographic regions.
4. Respond to, analyze, and make judgments about works in the visual arts. (Aesthetics, Valuing & Perspectives of Art)
Meaning and Informed Judgments
Ask questions about what is seen in art (reproductions) and student work displayed in the school or elsewhere, and state opinions, giving reasons, about aspects of works of art.

Discuss the objects in own works of art, using appropriate art vocabulary (e.g., color, shape, form, texture. Student holds art and says, "This is my mommy wearing a yellow color and me wearing blue stripes).
Discuss subject of the work and how it relates to the color, shape, form, and texture.
Discuss how and why students made a specific work of art and provide reasons why they like it, using appropriate art vocabulary.
Describe various reasons that he/she has made art in the way that it was done.
Discuss the subject of works of art created in the classroom, focusing on selected elements of art (e.g., shape, form, texture, line, color), and using appropriate art vocabulary.

Describe how and why students made a selected work of art, focusing on the media and technique and explain what the work means to them, what they like about their works of art and what they might change.
Describe what is seen, including both literal and expressive content, in selected works of art.
Compare the subjects, and elements of art and expressive content used in students' original work with those found in the works of others.
Articulate qualities in a work of art that make him/her like it and compare to qualities of good design .
Compare different responses to the same work of art in group discussion.
Describe the successful use of an element in one of student's works of art, using appropriate art vocabulary.
Contrast reactions to varying styles(e.g., stylized exaggeration, realism, impressionism, abstract, expressionism) of original works of art in a museum or gallery.

Respond to works of art and design using the critique process of determining:
  • What the artwork looks like (describe)
  • How it is made (describe)
  • How the parts of the artwork are arranged (analyze)
  • How the work affects feelings, mood, expresses ideas, or themes (interpret)
  • Is it successful? (judgment)
Compare and contrast appearance and content of selected works of art using appropriate vocabulary of art.
Judge own work against a rubric. Discuss what was successful or less successful in his/her work, giving reasons based on the visual characteristics.
Identify successful and less successful compositional qualities of student works of art using the principles of design and describe what might be done to improve them.
Look at public (outdoor) sculpture and determine what the artist was trying to express.

Analyze works of art and design using a critique process.:
  • Description of elements (describe)
  • How it was made (explain)
  • How the parts of the artwork are arranged as a whole (analyze)
  • How the work affects feelings or mood, and presents ideas or themes (interpret)
  • How the artwork is related to events in the artist's life themes (investigate/ interpret)
  • How it may relate to events or social trends of the period (investigate/interpret)
Discuss how the subject and selection of media relate to the meaning or purpose of a work of art.
Describe how the individual experiences of an artist may influence the development of specific works of art.
Using appropriate vocabulary of art, explain the successful compositional and communicative qualities of an artist's work.

Make judgments about works of art and design using a context and critique process involving elements of background history
  • Description (describe)
  • Technical qualities (explain & analyze)
  • Composition (analysis)
  • Meaning, theme, or message (interpret)
  • Perspective on interpretation of subject content
  • Expressive qualities (interpret)Relationship to period or society of origin (investigate/interpret)
  • Significance (judgment)
Analyze how works of art are organized by determining how the principles of design are used and how they affect personal responses and evaluation.
Develop and use specific criteria individually and in groups to assess works of art.
Using specific criteria, students assess their own works of art and describe what changes they would make for improvement

Construct and describe interpretations of what is perceived in works of art using aesthetic valuing vocabulary - the subject (the image viewers can identify), the composition (the way the principles of design are used to organize the elements of design), and content (the message the work communicates):
  • Subject
  • Composition
  • Content
  • Description
  • Significance
  • Merit
Judge own work against a rubric. Discuss what he/she liked about the work and what he/she did not like about the work, in writing, using appropriate visual and qualitative (aesthetic) vocabulary.
Identify and describe ways in which culture is reflected in current works of art.
Develop specific criteria alone or in groups to assess and critique works of art.
Articulate reasons for changing, editing, or revising personal works of art after a critique and museum visit.

Construct an interpretation of a work of art based on aesthetic valuing vocabulary- description (size, medium, process, subject, elements), analysis (how the work is organized, facts about the elements and principles), interpretation (the meaning, mood, message or idea the viewer feels the artist is trying to communicate) :
  • Subject
  • Composition
  • Content
  • Description
  • Analysis
  • Interpretation
Explain the intent of a personal work of art and draw possible parallels between it and the work of a recognized artist.
Develop and apply specific criteria individually or in groups to assess and critique works of art in writing.
Identify changes in a personal work of art and explain how those changes improved the work.

Verbalize interpretations of aesthetic valuing in writing and speaking about works of art, including judgment (determination of the degree of merit and whether the work is successful):
  • Subject
  • Composition
  • Content
  • Description
  • Analysis
  • Interpretation
  • Judgment
Present a reasoned argument about the artistic value of a work of art after viewing a museum reproduction. Respond to the arguments put forward by others within a classroom setting.

Develop and discuss possible theories about the artist's intent in a series of works of art, using reasoned statements to support personal opinions (e.g., Jacob Lawrence's Migration Series, Phillips Collection; Claude Monet's Rouen Cathedrals, National Gallery of Art).
Develop and apply specific criteria alone or in groups to assess and critique works of art.
Select a grouping of their own works of art that reflects growth over time and describe the progression based on the same criteria.
Derive Meaning

Employ the conventions of art criticism in writing and speaking about works of art:
  • Description
  • Visual Analysis Historical analysis (context)
  • Interpretation
  • Judgment

Assess examples works of art by historical or contemporary artists, using a set of criteria (rubric) and assess his/her own art using the same criteria, expressing (in writing) what was successful or less successful, giving reasons based on the visual characteristics.
Articulate how personal beliefs, cultural traditions, and current social, economic, and political contexts influence the interpretation of the meaning or message in a work of art.
Articulate how personal beliefs, cultural traditions, and current social, economic, and political contexts influence the judgment of merit works of art.
Use published sources, either traditional or electronic, to research a body of work or an artist, and present findings in written or oral form. View artist's original work in museum/gallery.
Articulate a process and rationale for refining and reworking an original student work of art.
Analyze the work of self and classmates stating facts about the elements and principles of design and effectiveness of communicated meaning in a class critique.
Formulate and support a position regarding the aesthetic value of a specific work of art viewed on museum Web site and change or defend that position after considering the opinions of others.
Analyze and articulate how society influences the interpretations and message of a work of art using art critiques from newspapers, periodicals, art journals, or texts.

Analyze a body of work, or the work of one artist, explaining its meaning and impact on society, symbolism, and visual metaphor, including the relationship between the artist, the art process, the artwork, and the viewer. Include observation and study of at least one original work in a museum or gallery.
Identify the intentions of artists creating contemporary works of art and explore the implications of those intentions.

Assess examples works of art by historical or contemporary artists, using a set of criteria (rubric) and assess his/her own art using the same criteria. Formulate in writing what was successful or less successful, giving reasons based on the visual characteristics.
Develop and apply written criteria for the selection of a body of work for individual student portfolios that represents significant technical and expressive achievements.
Apply various art-related theoretical perspectives to student's own works of art and the work of others in classroom critiques.
Construct a rationale for the validity of a specific work of art that falls outside of student's common conception of art. Observe and study the original work.
Choose an artist represented in a Washington, DC museum or gallery to study and respond with their own series of artworks and a written commentary
5. Connect and apply what is learned in the visual arts to other art forms, subject areas, visual culture and communications and to careers. (Connections, Relationships, Applications)
Connections and Applications
Name colors and draw an object using the colors (e.g., yellow flower, red apple, blue lunch box, green leaves, brown tree, orange fruit, purple grapes).
Recognize, describe, duplicate, extend, and create simple patterns. (Connection to mathematics)
Create visual patterns (e.g., line, line, dot; line, line, dot) to match rhythms made by clapping or drumming the beat found in selected poems or songs.
Draw lines (e.g., curved, straight, parallel) to represent movements used in play.
Draw geometric shapes (e.g., circles, squares, triangles) and repeat them in dance/movement sequences.
Look at and draw something used every day (e.g., scissors, toothbrush, fork) and describe how the object is used.
Clap out rhythmic patterns found in the lyrics of music and use symbols to create visual representations of the patterns.
Recognize symbols/icons used in the country and local community (e.g., U.S. flag, dollar sign, monuments).
Use various techniques to show opposites (e.g., up/down, in/out, over/under, in front of/behind, together/apart, far/near, fast/slow, stop/go).
Select and use expressive colors to create mood and to show the personality of a hero (from long ago to the present) in a portrait.
Create a folded paper book (using book arts) on the subject of reading or mathematics content (e.g., vocabulary pictures, multiplication facts).
Represent and construct architectural features (e.g., arches, columns, symmetry, domes, post and beam) identifying mathematical concepts.
Describe how costumes contribute to the meaning of a dance.

Write and illustrate a book (using book arts) implementing the writing process (e.g., prewriting, drafting, revising, editing/proofreading, publishing/presenting) demonstrating a unified drawing style.
Identify through research twentieth-century artists who have used symmetry in their work and then create a work of art, using bilateral or radial symmetry.

Write and illustrate a book (using book arts) implementing the writing process (e.g., prewriting, drafting, revising, editing/proofreading, publishing/presenting) demonstrating a unified drawing style.
Use linear perspective to depict geometric objects in space.
Interpret an abstract painting relating it to dance/ movement.
Design a poster that illustrates a theme.
Research how traditional characters (such as the trickster) found in a variety of cultures past and present are represented in illustrations.
Write a poem or story inspired by original works of art.
Write and illustrate a journal using the writing process (e.g., prewriting, drafting, revising, editing/proofreading, publishing/presenting).
Create a line design using a variety of angles, triangles, quadrilaterals, and polygons. Identify the lines and shapes used.
Create a tessellation showing a translation, reflection or rotation. Distinguish the three types.

Construct a book (using book arts) combining text and illustration using the writing process (e.g., prewriting, drafting, revising, editing/proofreading, publishing/ presenting), that summarizes information.
Study the music and art of a selected historical era and create a multimedia presentation that reflects that time and culture.
Use mathematical ratios and proportions to represent the human figure.
Use various drawing skills and techniques to depict lifestyles and scenes from selected civilizations.
Research and present the ways art illustrates and/or commemorates historical people and events through sculpture, paintings, photographs, and maps.

Construct a book (using book arts) combining text and illustration using the writing process (e.g., prewriting, drafting, revising, editing/proofreading, publishing/ presenting), that summarizes information, relates new information, and extends ideas.
Select a favorite artist and some of his or her works of art and create a music video that expresses personal ideas and views about the artist.
Create a painting, satirical drawing, or editorial cartoon that expresses personal opinions about current social or political issues.
Design a poster that illustrates a theme.
Create a design for a child-friendly play space in a park-like setting, inspired by architectural styles from Washington, DC monuments.
Create a work of art that communicates a cross-cultural or universal theme taken from literature or history.

Create a unified literary work combining text and illustration using the writing process (e.g., prewriting, drafting, revising, editing/proofreading, publishing/presenting), that summarizes information, relates new information, and extends ideas. The literary text and visuals should explain the theme, viewpoint and setting.
Create a pattern which demonstrates symmetry of geometric figures.
Produce a drawing or painting using various types of polygons in an architectural setting.
Illustrate or sculpt a commemoration of a historical person or event producing a painting, photography, a map, or 3-dimensional media.
Design an advertising campaign for a theatre or dance production held at a school, creating images that represent characters and major events in the production.
Illustrate and describe the structure and function of biological forms.

Create a gallery and museum guide for young adults. Research several galleries and museums and using the internet create an annotated list of exhibitions that would appeal to middle and high school students. Design an interactive activity to focus a visit.
Apply art and design as a means of understanding global issues.
Explore cultural comparisons and contrasts in developing themes and universal understanding connected to world language and health and physical education.
Speculate on how advances in technology might change the definition and function of the visual arts.

Visit a specialized library collection to view a work of art or manuscript in collection storage or study rooms; note the setting, special environmental conditions, display, and preservation requirements.
Produce a drawing or painting using various types of polygons and polyhedrons to solve visual problems.
Determine size and proportion of illustrated objects by measuring dimensions, area and volume.
Illustrate and describe the cycles of biotic (living) and abiotic (non-living such as a rock, the sky, air) factors in an ecosystem.

Create a mock-up of a site-specific building or public art piece and write a proposal articulating how it serves the location and community for which it is designed. Address relevance to aesthetic, social, environmental, cultural, political issues as appropriate.
Research the role in the community, the operations and curatorial processes of a local art gallery.
Apply art and design as a means of problem solving global issues.
Create a game that represents a set of data using a 3-D modeling software program.
Design a computer-generated image that demonstrates the function of visual arts technology (motion, space and perception).
Visual Literacy
Identify images of self, friends, and family (including snapshots and students' own works of art).
Identify art forms (e.g., photographs, paintings, murals, ceramics, sculptures) and images found at home, in school, and in the community.

Recognize American symbols (flag colors and shapes, monuments, the statue of Liberty) and symbols used in commercial products created by artists and designers that can be seen at an art museum such as the Corcoran Gallery of Art.
Identify and sort pictures into categories according to the elements of art emphasized in the works (e.g., color, line, shape, form, texture).
Identify and sort pictures into categories according to subject, theme and mood.
Look at images in figurative works of art and predict what might happen next, telling what clues in the work support their ideas.
Draw diagrams, maps, graphs, timelines, or illustrations to communicate ideas or tell a story about a historical event.
Identify and design icons, logos, and other graphic devices as symbols for ideas and information. Write how the design represents the idea or information.
Describe tactics employed in advertising to sway the viewer's thinking and provide examples.

Examine art, photography, and other two- and three-dimensional images in order to compare how different visual representations of the same object lead to different interpretations of its meaning, and describe or illustrate the results.
Demonstrate an understanding of the effects of visual communication media (e.g., television, music videos, film, Internet) on various aspects of society.
Compare and contrast the ways in which different media (television, newspapers, magazines) cover the same art exhibition. .
Write an introductory text panel and labels to accompany a student-organized exhibition using the language of the art world
Compare and contrast works of art, probing beyond the obvious and identifying psychological content found in the symbols and images.
Identify one or more issues raised by a political work of art, based upon visual clues. Discuss the power of art to challenge and provoke the viewer.

Compose a brochure essay that articulates the style, impact, and unifying theme of an exhibition of world culture, using visual and/or literary arts vocabulary as well as art historical and culture-specific language and concepts.
Careers and Career-Related Skills
Discuss how art is used to illustrate story books, texts, comics, and cartoons on television and computers.
Discuss the design of everyday objects (e.g. cereal box, toothpaste and toy box packaging, chairs, telephone).
Describe objects designed by artists (e.g., furniture, appliances, cars) that are used at home and at school.
Find examples of various works of art in the city (e.g., murals, paintings, sculpture), discuss their purpose, and type of media used.
Identify artists in the community who create different kinds of art (e.g., prints, ceramics, paintings, illustrations, sculpture, buildings).
Read biographies and stories about artists and summarize the readings in short reports, telling how the artists mirrored or affected their time periods or culture.
Research and report on what various types of artists (e.g., architects, designers, graphic artists, animators) produce and how their works play a role in our everyday environment.
Establish criteria to use in selecting works of art for a specific type of art exhibition.

Access a variety of resources such as books, a CD-ROM or visit a museum website to research an artist or art movement; share new information with classmates, e.g. National Gallery of Art: www.nga.gov; The Metropolitan Museum of Art's Timeline of Art History: www.metmuseum.org/toah; Art Institute of Chicago: www.artic.edu/aic/collections/index.php.

Identify professions in or related to the visual arts and some of the specific skills needed for those professions e.g. studio artist, art educator, web designer, stone mason, architect, curator, museum educator.

Invite a local artist to work on a project in the school. Recognize how an artist plans a project, prepares materials, executes the project, involves the school community, extends learning and makes a positive impact on the learning environment.
Visit a local artist or designer in his/her studio; notice how the artist organizes the studio; observe his/her work habits; and learn how the artist contributes to the community.
Work collaboratively with a community artist to create a work of art, such as a mural and write a report about the skills needed to become a professional artist.
Demonstrate an understanding of the various skills of an artist (e.g., art critic, art historian, art collector, art gallery owner, art therapist, and philosopher of art/ aesthetician).
Research visual arts and design careers and post-secondary institutions that provide training.
Investigate and report on the essential features of modern or emerging technologies that affect or will affect visual artists and the definition of the visual arts.
Develop career tools such as a professional quality portfolio, a resume, cover letters, and competition entries.
Research and participate in pre-college programs, (e.g. student portfolio days) at colleges and universities, such as the Corcoran College of Art and Design.
